passage_text: Definition of NATALISM. : an attitude or policy favoring or encouraging population growth. — na·ta·list \-ələ̇st\ noun plural. ADVERTISEMENT.
Antinatalism is a philosophical position that assigns a negative value to birth, standing in opposition to natalism.

Natalism (also called pronatalism or the pro-birth position) is a belief that promotes human reproduction. The term is taken from the Latin adjective form for birth, natalis. Natalism promotes child-bearing and parenthood as desirable for social reasons and to ensure national continuance.

Natalism in public policy typically seeks to create financial and social incentives for populations to reproduce, such as providing tax incentives that reward having and supporting children. Adherents of more stringent takes on natalism may seek to limit access to abortion and contraception, as well.

Posted on October 5, 2010 by ahaefliger. The aim of anti-natalist policies is to decrease the total fertility rate, as well as the crude birth rate, in order to slow the population growth. These policies are seen in countries of rapid population growth like China, India, or a few decades ago Singapore.
